Posts.Content: On 2/1/2007 Dee in va wrote: Two years ago I had recurrence of breast cancer, eight years and 1 day after the first diagnosis.  The first time, I had lumpectomy/node disection/chemo/radiation.  The recurrence felt like the rug was pulled out from under me.  I NEVER wanted to go through this again, so I opted for a double mastectomy, which was done in May, 2005.  Followed by three chemo treatments (was supposed to be four, but I blacked out a few days after # 3, and broke my leg - which didn't heal for 4 months because of the chemo).  I had immediate reconstruction with tissue expanders, and eventually saline implants, followed by nipple reconstruction, and tommorow I get the nipples/areolas tattooed.  What I was NOT told at the time I was making my reconstruction decision was that there is a procedure that reconstructs a very natural looking and feeling breast from your own abdominal skin and fat, without taking abdominal muscle.  The procedure is lengthy (8 hrs) but the results are very natural.  I'm not sure if I would have chosen this at the time, but I sure would have liked to have had the info, so I could have considered it.  I had a bad experience with my first plastic surgeon, who didn't even tell me that (at the time) silicone implants were still considered experimental.  I only found out the day before I was scheduled for the surgery, and then it was a phone call from an office scheduler telling me that my surgery was cancelled because "they (the hospital where it was scheduled) don't participate in the study". (Of course, I asked "WHAT study???", and it went downhill from there - I really had no trust in that doctor after this occured.)  Anyway, I have saline implants, and no, I don't "like" them.  they don't feel natural, and they aren't perfect (the side that I had the radiation on when originally diagnosed has a "flat spot", where the skin didn't stretch much.)  The CDC puts out a very detailed packet of info on breast reconstruction, you can get it on-line (search for "CDC", then breast reconstruction.)  It tells you what my frist plastic surgeon never mentioned to me:  implants have to be replaced at some point- you should expect mutliple surgeries for the initial reconstruction, and then at some future point in time.  Would I do it again?  Maybe.  I wanted reconsturction so I wouldn't have that visual reminder every time I got dressed/undressed, but to tell you the truth, there is more scarring than I expected and more surgeries under general anesthesia than I anticipated (the initial mastectomies and expanders, the "exchange" of the expanders for the implants, and a second surgery to revise the first (first plastic surgeon hadn't put them in right), plus the multiple visits for expansion, and now the tattoos.  I was initially told that I would be "DONE" with reconstruction before Christmas of 2005.  Here it is, closer to two years after the mastectomies, and I am finally finishing up!  Get as much info as you can, and then decide.  Also, remember that you don't have to have reconstruction right away, it can wait.

Posts.Content: Hi Jan,  Like you, I have no regrets for the surgery choice I made.  They did find that the tumor was quite a bit larger than they originally thought, it was not in the lymph nodes but had eaten through a blood vessel prior to surgery.  I feel really good, have not had any depression or regrets and went back to work today.  I still have two drain tubes in, it seems like I may never get rid of those, they are so inconvientent  to work around.  I go next week for my chemo workup and then will probably start it around the 15th of March.  It sounds like about 12 weeks of that but it isn't set in stone yet.  How did chemo affect you?  I have alot of reservations about it but know that it is the best choice, I just don't know enough about it to even ask intelligent questions.  The one nurse I talked to at the chemo center said she didn't think it would make me sick as much as it would just make me extremely tired. Hope she's right.  I appreciate any advice and input that you might have.  Judy

Posts.Content: On 2/2/2007 Janie Rocks wrote:   On 2/2/2007 Pcola2006 wrote:   On 1/31/2007 Judy1957 wrote: I was diagnosed about 3 weeks ago with DCIS.  It is in beginning stages of being invasive but doesn't seem to be in the lymph nodes yet.  My family has a I was diagnosed on July 5, 2006.  I chose to have a double on July 21,2006 because I knew I could never face this again.  I was not able to do my reconstruction at the same time because my plastic surgeon was on vacation and I just wanted the cancer under control and decided not to wait even a week.  I am glad because this has given me time to research and decide which way I want to go.  I have also gained about 20 pounds and would like to not have this when I have my next surgery.  I walk at least a mile a day on the treadmill and try to watch what I eat, I have 3 more taxol treatments and then I will start harmone therapy and will continue with herceptin.  For me personally, waiting has been right.  I have had so much time to think and adjust.  I will answer any questions you have and will pray for you.  Good Luck  Hello;  I had a bilateral almost 8 years ago by choice and reconstruction immediately.  I 've never been sorry about the decision to go bi-lateral, only about the choice to have reconstruction at the same time.   If I had it to do over again I would wait and do more research on which way to go. I think it is a wise decision to take both breasts, especially with your history.  It isn't that hard to get over having both removed and I think you wil be happy not to have the stress and worry about finding cancer in the breast that is left if you don't have both removed.  I wish you the best outcome possible and feel free to respond or ask any questions you might have. My name is Janie and I live in Illinois.  Hi Janie,  I just wanted to tell you thanks for your input.  My surgery went well and I am back to work.  I really am thinking at this point to not even do reconstruction.  I still have two drain tubes in and I would guess they go with reconstruction as well, that alone makes me think it probably isn't worth it.  They had thought my cancer was in stage 1, lymph nodes were clean but when pathology came back, it had eaten through a blood vessel so it went systemic in a different direction, don't know if that is good or bad compared to it invading the lymph nodes, but I'm thinking it isn't real good.  Start chemo in about two weeks.  I feel good for now but will be glad when this is behind.  Thanks for your support.  Judy

Posts.Content: I was diagnosed about 3 weeks ago with DCIS.  It is in beginning stages of being invasive but doesn't seem to be in the lymph nodes yet.  My family has a history of breast cancer and my surgeon is in agreement that a bilateral will probably be a good choice as this is probably genetic.  I would appreciate input from those of you who have had the bilateral done, does it feel like it was the wrong decision and what are your thoughts on reconstruction.  My surgery is scheduled for the 13th of Feb.
